The American chairman of the commission investigating complaints about last Thursday's presidential polls in Afghanistan says some of the charges his team is reviewing are serious enough to affect the outcome.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson has more from Kabul.
At a news conference, Grant Kippen said the election complaints commission he chairs received 225 complaints from around Afghanistan.

The allegations contained in the complaints we've received so far range from voter intimidation, violence, ballot-box tampering, interference in the polling, polling stations not opening and problems with the indelible ink.
The ink was used to stain voters' fingers to prevent them from casting ballots more than once.
Kippen said the more serious charges they are looking into came from provinces where Taliban gun and bomb attacks affected voter turnout and prevented independent monitors from going to the polls.
He said that 35 of the complaints are so serious that they could affect the final results.
But I think it's important to point out that in order to do a proper investigation, we require as much information as possible about these particular irregularities.
It's not enough to just say there was voting fraud somewhere.
We need to know where it took place and when it took place.
That's been difficult, he said, because of the delays in moving ballots and complaints from individual polling centers to Afghan independent election commission headquarters here in Kabul.
Preliminary election results are expected as early as Tuesday, although Kippen said it's too early to set any final date for certifying the results.
Also unclear at this point is whether the election will go to a runoff in early October.
That would happen if neither incumbent President Hamid Karzai nor his challengers get more than 50 percent of the vote.
In the western city of Herat, U.S.

Special Envoy Richard Holbrooke, in an interview with the Associated Press today, cautioned against rushing to judgment on the credibility of the election until the complaints process has run its course.

A congressional committee is investigating the State Department's investigators.
The Inspector General's Office there is supposed to ferret out fraud and abuse within the State Department.
Now the chairman of the House Government Oversight Committee has written a letter accusing the inspector general of squelching investigations to protect the Bush administration's image.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.

California Democrat Henry Waxman was tipped off that there were problems at the State Department Inspector General's Office after his House committee started looking into the building of a massive new U.S.
Embassy in Baghdad.
There were allegations that one of the contractors, a Kuwaiti company, brought in foreign workers against their will.

Waxman says rather than sending experienced investigators to look into the allegations of human trafficking, the State Department's inspector general, a political appointee named Howard Krongard did the report himself.
He made a report based on his own interviews, but he only interviewed people that the contractor wanted him to interview.
And then after only talking to those people, he exonerated the company.
Waxman says Krongard refused to cooperate in a Department of Justice investigation into other problems with the U.S.
Embassy compound.
It seems from what we're hearing from people in the State Department that he was deciding to be a good partisan Republican and not do anything that might embarrass the Bush administration.
But he wasn't, according to these allegations, doing his job of finding out about wasted and perhaps fraudulent takings of U.S.
taxpayers' money.
Krongard's office released a statement saying the inspector general is traveling in Afghanistan and Iraq now.
It said the letter Waxman wrote is replete with inaccuracies, including those made by persons with their own agendas.
One of the whistleblowers quoted in Waxman's letter is Ralph McNamara, who now works in the Inspector General's Office of the U.S.
Postal Service.
He says he was basically pushed out of the State Department.
I was called into the office for a meeting with the inspector general, the deputy inspector general.
And I was told that I was the last of the old management and that I was to step aside.
McNamara says while he was on the job, he tried to follow leads from State Department officials out in the field who report back problems through a special hotline.
He remembers some complaints about a contractor that was supposed to provide a certain type of computer for a police training facility in Afghanistan.
We had folks contact the hotline and say it was not that particular brand, it was a counterfeit, and second, the software was not the software that was called for.
And there were some indication that there may have been a back door put in the computers that allow hackers or even worse access to the files on the computer instant access to network.
McNamara says investigators couldn't go to follow-up.
Many other tips were simply ignored.
Now my thing, all of these allegations would have been proved true?
No. But why take the chance?
I mean, you've got lives.
You've got millions of dollars on the line.
McNamara said he came forward not for any personal grudges, but because he felt it was the right thing to do for U.S.
officials serving abroad and for U.S.
taxpayers.
He says there are few investigators left on the job at the State Department's Inspector General's Office.
And those who remain are frustrated.
Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
